senses.de: Equal in value, amount, function, or meaning
senses.ex: A life sentence is equivalent to 25 years in prison.

Tips.title: Value Equivalence
Tips.description: Use 'equivalent' to compare things that can replace each other due to similar value.
Tips.example: An e-book might be considered equivalent to a printed copy in content.

Tips.title: Not Always Interchangeable
Tips.description: 'Equivalent' suggests equality but doesn't mean the two can always be used interchangeably.
Tips.example: An assistant manager's duties are equivalent to those of a manager, but the titles aren't interchangeable.

senses.de: One thing that is the same as another thing in certain ways
senses.ex: To him, lying and stealing are equivalent crimes.

Tips.title: Broad Comparisons
Tips.description: Use 'equivalent' to speak broadly about similar things, even if they're not exactly the same.
Tips.example: For vegans, tofu is an equivalent source of protein to meat.

Tips.title: Context Matters
Tips.description: The context in which 'equivalent' is used can imply positive or negative comparisons.
Tips.example: Some say fast food's convenience is the equivalent of home-cooked meal's wholesomeness.

senses.de: Having the same or a similar effect or result
senses.ex: These two sentences are equivalent in meaning.

Tips.title: Effect Equality
Tips.description: When comparing actions, 'equivalent' stresses that they lead to the same result, not that they're the same action.
Tips.example: Walking for an hour is equivalent in exercise to running for 30 minutes.

Tips.title: Perception Variance
Tips.description: Different listeners might perceive 'equivalent' differently based on their personal views.
Tips.example: To some, a high-five is equivalent in friendliness to a handshake.

senses.de: A person or thing that performs the same function as another
senses.ex: A lieutenant in the navy is equivalent to a captain in the army.

Tips.title: Functional Equivalence
Tips.description: Emphasize function, not form, when considering if two roles or objects are 'equivalent'.
Tips.example: A smartphone can be the equivalent of a computer for certain tasks.

Tips.title: Rank and Responsibility
Tips.description: Use 'equivalent' to compare hierarchical positions in different systems of rank.
Tips.example: In some companies, a 'Director' is equivalent to a 'Senior Manager' in others.

senses.de: An amount or quantity of something that is equivalent to something else
senses.ex: In terms of calories, 30 minutes of jogging is equivalent to one chocolate bar.

Tips.title: Mathematical Precision
Tips.description: In math, 'equivalent' means two expressions represent the same value exactly, without approximation.

Tips.title: Quantitative Measure
Tips.description: Quantities can be 'equivalent' when they're expressed differently but represent the same amount.
Tips.example: One liter is equivalent to 1000 milliliters.

Commensurate.wordDefinition:
When something is commensurate, it means that it is equal in measure or proportion to something else. For example, if you get paid a salary that is commensurate with your skills and experience, it means that you are paid a fair amount based on those factors.

Commensurate describes something that is proportional to something else, while equivalent describes something that is equal in value or function to something else.

Correspond.wordDefinition:
Correspond implies similarity or compatibility between two things, while equivalent suggests that two things have the same value or meaning.

For example, if you are learning a new language, you may find that a word in English corresponds to a word in another language, meaning that they have a similar meaning and can be used in similar ways.

Correspond is used when describing things that are similar or match up in some way, while equivalent describes things that are essentially the same.

Equal.wordDefinition:
Equal means that two things are exactly the same in size, amount or value. For example, 5 is equal to 5 or 1 dollar is equal to 100 cents.

Equivalent means that two things are similar or interchangeable. It implies that even though they might not be exactly the same, they can be considered as equal in certain situations.

To summarize, equal refers to things that are exactly the same while equivalent refers to things that are comparable, similar or interchangeable.

Identical.wordDefinition:
Equivalent means having the same value, function or meaning as another thing, while not necessarily being identical in appearance or form.

Identical means being exactly the same in appearance or form. For example, identical twins have the same DNA, which makes them look almost exactly alike.

In math, two equations are identical if they have exactly the same terms and expressions.

Equivalent is used when things have the same value or function, while identical is used when things are exactly the same in appearance or form.

Parallel.wordDefinition: Parallel means that two things are side by side and never cross paths. For instance, two parallel lines in geometry do not intersect.

Resemble.wordDefinition: Resemble means to be similar or alike in appearance or nature. For example, two people may resemble each other in the way they look.

Same.wordDefinition:
Equivalent means two things that have the same value, but may look different or be used in different ways. For example, one dollar is equivalent to four quarters.

They are not exactly the same, but they have the same value.

Same means two things that are identical or exactly alike. For example, if you have two apples that are the same, they look exactly alike and have the same characteristics.

Equivalent means two things that have the same value, but may not be the same physically or functionally, while same means two things that are identical or exactly alike.

Tantamount.wordDefinition:
Tantamount means being equal to something in seriousness, effect, or consequence. For example, disobeying your parents is tantamount to breaking the law.

In simpler terms, equivalent refers to things that have the same value or meaning, while tantamount refers to things that have the same level of importance or seriousness.

quotes.Title: Chinese Designer
quotes.Name: Jenova Chen

quotes.Text: Usually, there is no equivalent of air traffic control at sea. Some busy areas operate 'traffic separation schemes,' but mostly, ships are treated like cars on roads where there are rules and codes of behavior, and successful, accident-free outcomes depend on everyone respecting them. As on roads, this doesn't always work.
quotes.Title: British Journalist
quotes.Name: Rose George

quotes.Text: I need to know how many records I've sold, how many album equivalents from streaming, which territories are playing my music more than others, because it helps me in conversations about where we're gonna be playing shows or where I might open a retail location, like a pop-up store or something.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Frank Ocean

quotes.Text: I am willing to admit that if the agriculturists are oppressed by peculiar burdens, they ought to be relieved from them, or be allowed a fair and just protection equivalent to all such peculiar burdens.
quotes.Title: Scottish Scientist
quotes.Name: Joseph Hume

quotes.Text: I believe deeply that jazz is still a very vital music that has much to say, not just to eggheads, or whatever the musical equivalent of an egghead is, but to ordinary people.
quotes.Title: American Critic
quotes.Name: Terry Teachout

quotes.Text: To bring a child into the world that you cannot feed, clothe, house, and educate is the moral equivalent, in my opinion, of a drive-by shooting.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Larry Elder

quotes.Text: We should have equivalent due-process protections for algorithmic decisions as for human decisions.
quotes.Title: Australian Writer
quotes.Name: Kate Crawford

quotes.Text: Crime against the individual is the equivalent of crime against humanity.
quotes.Title: Iranian Statesman
quotes.Name: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad

quotes.Text: Achieving life is not the equivalent of avoiding death.
quotes.Title: Russian Writer
quotes.Name: Ayn Rand

quotes.Text: There can be no literary equivalent to truth.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: Laura Riding
